title: Nick Bolton, Antony Catalano and the mystery $5m deal
text:
That was two days after Keybridge deposited $5 million into a trust account held by law firm Ashurst. The former Domain chief and the billionaire remain ACM's only shareholders, though it sounds like only one of their stakes is unencumbered.

Catalano and Bolton were previously on the same side of an attempt to derail Nine's 2018 takeover of Fairfax Media, publisher of this newspaper, which achieved nothing beyond column inches. Could Bolton have subsequently helped fund Catalano's entry into Fairfax’s regional papers?

Bolton said: "Catalano does not have our $5 million", adding that the media executive has "plenty of money of his own". He also stated that Catalano was "not the transaction counter-party". Catalano did not address a question about whether he was or had ever been in negotiations with Bolton about Keybridge's $5 million.

Last week, Keybridge told the ASX it was in "ongoing discussions with the counter-party to the proposed transaction in an attempt to resolve impediments to the transaction completing as originally intended". That would be because the terms of Keybridge’s payment remain unresolved.

Major concern

"Until these discussions conclude, [Keybridge] has elected to not immediately call for the payment to be returned. [Keybridge] has, however, obtained a personal guarantee from the transaction principal to ensure it has a security satisfactory to the Keybridge board for the ability to obtain return of the payment."

The transaction was an issue of major concern to Keybridge's board, control of which is split between nominees of the Bolton-controlled Aurora and the Farooq Khan-controlled Bentley.

It also raised alarm bells at Deloitte, which audits Keybridge. The firm's auditors state in Keybridge's annual report that they have been unable to ensure "certain transactions recorded in the Group's accounting records were appropriately authorised and undertaken for the group's benefit".

Advertisement

"The matters are so material and pervasive to the financial report that we are unable to express an opinion on the financial report taken as a whole."

In Perth’s Federal Court earlier this month, a judge dismissed attempts by directors aligned with Bolton and with Khan to dismiss each other from the Keybridge board. Dissatisfied with the Bolton-aligned Keybridge chairman John Patton’s explanation of the $5 million investment, Khan had passed a motion to dismiss him as chairman. The Court overruled that, as well as Khan’s own removal by Patton.

Given Bolton's rap sheet with the corporate regulators, his (indirect) financial backing of The Canberra Times, Newcastle Herald and Illawarra Mercury becoming public would presumably be a little mortifying for their proprietors.
description: Two days before Nine sold Australian Community Media, Keybridge Capital made an intriguing transfer.
